topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5368778e6368721b29040000#post_5368778e6368721b29040000

"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536878c2636872264a500000#post_536878c2636872264a500000
Nope; less than ten years.  The reason why is that we already have the technology for mass production, but the problem right now is that it would cost twice as much for a burger patty.  I say ten years cause five years until it starts getting cheap enough to be realistic and another five years it passes the FDA for being safe.


Actually this could very well save the human race.  The reason why there's two billion people on the planet that struggle to survive is because they're too poor to afford food and so forth.  If you replace current food production with synthesized food then not only will that make being able to afford food a reality, but the amount of farmland needed in the world drastically allowing for nature to retake most of the land used.  Imagine how much that would change the world to have all the land we use for farming to allow nature to retake it considering that the largest reason for deforestation is to make new farmland.  Now imagine how much that would reduce pollution.

"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687ac963687264e92a0000#post_53687ac963687264e92a0000
No one is saying you would have to eat synthesized food, but think about it from another perspective; are you really saying a technology that can save *BILLIONS* of lives is something that people shouldn't as a whole embrace under the pretence of it not being natural and therefore wrong?  Are you really saying that *BILLIONS* of people deserve to die cause technology isn't natural?
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687a5963687252db440000#post_53687a5963687252db440000
We will still get a lot of bacteria from the environment. So I wouldn't worry too much about that. Vaccines provoke immune responses as well, and we will still have plenty of those.

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687c85636872097b370000#post_53687c85636872097b370000
Sorry, but I could never eat food that comes from a machine. Real food has natural vitamins, minerals, proteins, fats and enzymes that no machine could possibly make. Keep in mind your body is _designed_ to eat natural food found in nature, trying to force synthetic food into it is like trying to force a square peg into a round hole.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687d216368727c3ad60000#post_53687d216368727c3ad60000
Instead of fake food, how about growing real food in barren regions? We could take all the scraps from our crops and compost them into fertilizer and mix it with soil and ship it off to parts of the world with poor growing conditions. We could also grow amaranth, an incredibly resilient crop that is very nutritious and can stand almost any type of climate.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687e216368721481170100#post_53687e216368721481170100
Animal populations follow bell curves too.  All this new technology would do is bring endangered animals back from the brink of extinction.

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687e7f6368721481660100#post_53687e7f6368721481660100
Golden Rice was made to help with vitamin A deficiency in third-world countries, and it is public, not corporate. That makes it a lot better than Monsanto's Roundup Ready crops. Other vitamin A-containing foods are either seasonal, unavailable or too expensive. I think Golden Rice avoids most of the problems that other GMOs have.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687e7f6368721481660100#post_53687e7f6368721481660100
[bq="someguy111"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53687d216368727c3ad60000#post_53687d216368727c3ad60000
Instead of fake food, how about growing real food in barren regions? We could take all the scraps from our crops and compost them into fertilizer and mix it with soil and ship it off to parts of the world with poor growing conditions. We could also grow amaranth, an incredibly resilient crop that is very nutritious and can stand almost any type of climate.[/bq]
*BZZT! Wrong again!
That wouldn't be enough to sustain the entire population of the earth.


The benefits of synthesized food:
Billions of people would stop going hungry every night.
Saving billions of lives.
Preventing widespread spreading of diseases through food.
Preventing contaminated food.
Massively reduced health problems due to fast food.
Worldwide reforestation and as a result bringing countless species back from being endangered and as a result massively helping with global warming and pollution.
Massively reducing our oil usage.
Preventing on a large scale the transmission of diseases from animal to humans from food.


. . . . Since I'm not getting this through to you let me ask you a question then, have you ever gone hungry or thirsty?  No no, I don't mean fasting for a day or you forget drink fluids.  I mean legitimately hungry for weeks to the point you lose fifty pounds.  Do you know how that feels?  Do you have any inkling of a idea of how that feels?  What about being thirsty?  Do you have any idea of how that feels to go days without water?  I have.  You have never gone hungry or thirsty and doesn't know how painful it is.  Imagine gripping your stomach screaming cause you're in so much pain.  Now tell me that telling billions of people that they deserve that daily because your beliefs are more important than their lives.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5368813a63687278c1320000#post_5368813a63687278c1320000
As I said, those are either unavailable, only available seasonally, or too expensive for families in underdeveloped countries. Also, unlike "GMO Scuba Rice":http://nextcity.org/daily/entry/scientists-develop-lab-created-scuba-rice-that-can-stand-up-to-climate-chan, they cannot survive flooding. So GMO food technology is still useful.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5368808b6368724d0e0f0100#post_5368808b6368724d0e0f0100
I never said billions deserve to go hungry, quite the opposite in fact. If we could just grow good food in barren countries like Ethiopia using fertile soil the hunger problems would be well on their way to being solved. Again, the US and many other countries have more crop waste than they know what to do with, not to mention homeowners with all of their grass clippings and leaves they need to dispose of. All of that could be collected and turned into compost with could be used to fertilize crops in regions of the world where they are hard to grow. Our waste would be the fertilizer for a big chunk of their food.

Cheap food is just that though-cheap. Food that's produced by big corporations for the sake of profit and grown in synthetic fertilizers and pesticides and possibly exposed to radiation. Real food, like the kind the human body is supposed to eat, grows naturally with little to no human intervention. Sure we could feed the people of the world the food Americans eat, hut don't be surprised when half of them drop dead from heart attacks from all the saturated fats or develop obesity.
